discussion.content:
In an operating system, a fork is a Unix or Linux system call to create a new process from an existing running process. The new process is a child process of the calling parent process.

https://www.computerhope.com/jargon/f/fork.htm#:~:text=1.,of%20the%20calling%20parent%20process.

questions.question_text: Which definition of a fork in Linux is true?

choices.B: parentdirectory name of a file path name
choices.D: new process created by a parent process

questions.question_text: Which two terms are types of cross site scripting attacks? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:

The book further references https://supportforums.cisco.com/document/13113946/what-are-cross-site-scripting-xss-vulnerabilities but unfortunately it's no longer available ;<

choices.A: Forging a TCP packet over an HTTPS session
choices.D: Modifying the TCP/IP in a way that is unexpected by security detection
choices.B: Replacing legitimate TCP traffic with forged TCP packets
choices.C: The addition of a forged TCP packet to an existing TCP session

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a TCP-injection attack?

comments.content: Answer C is correct because this does not modify the legitimate traffic and act over HTTP. Answer A is incorrect because this doesn’t work over HTTPS. Answer B is incorrect because this attack doesn’t modify the legitimate traffic. Answer D doesn’t provide enough detail.

choices.A: the number of bits in the host field

questions.question_text: What determines the class of an IP address?

discussion.content:
The answer provided is correct. MSB pattern will be continuous 1s starting from the left.
See https://www.techtarget.com/whatis/definition/most-significant-bit-or-byte#:~:text=The%20most%20significant%20bit%20(MSB,0111%2C%20the%20MSB%20is%200.
The answer should be the first octet of the IP address, so MSB, meaning the first eight bits of the ip address would determine which class the IP address belongs to.

comments.content: Okay, it depends on your understanding of the term "host field".

In classful networking, the amount of bits in the host field gets defined by the class you are in, not the other way around. The most significant (left) bits determine what class the IP belongs to, eg:
- If the first bit of the first octet is 0, then it's a class A network. 
- If the first bit is 1 and the second one is 0, then it's a class B network
etc...
Given answer is correct. The private class C is from 192.168.0.0 to 192.168.255.255 . Ref. https://www.ibm.com/docs/en/networkmanager/4.2.0?topic=translation-private-address-ranges .

discussion.content:
Aren't 
192.168.0.0 – 192.168.255.255 and 192.168.1.0 – 192.168.1.255 both Class C?
At least when calculating online it says they're both class C :x
